instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the study for verifying the accuracy of label declarations for marine oil dietary supplements containing EPA and DHA?
Output: The study used two types of spectra: portable Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra from a portable FTIR device and benchtop Fourier transform near infrared (FT-NIR) spectra from a benchtop FT-NIR spectrometer.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the study for verifying the accuracy of label declarations for marine oil dietary supplements containing EPA and DHA?
Output: Savitzky Golay first derivative spectral preprocessing was used in the study for verifying the accuracy of label declarations for marine oil dietary supplements containing EPA and DHA.

instruction: What metric was chosen in the study for verifying the accuracy of label declarations for marine oil dietary supplements containing EPA and DHA and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen in the related study is the accuracy of prediction, which is measured by the root mean square error of prediction (RMSEP) and the correlation coefficient (R-2). The study found that the support vector regression (SV-R) models had higher accuracy and predictive quality compared to the partial least squares regression (PLS-R) models. The SV-R models showed up to 2.4 times higher accuracy for predicting fatty acid (FA) and FA class concentrations in marine oil dietary supplements using both ATR-FTIR and FT-NIR spectroscopic data. The SV-R models also provided closer agreement with the certified and reference values for the prediction of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in the reference standard. Therefore, the SV-R method with spectroscopic data can potentially be used for the rapid screening of marine oil products to verify the accuracy of label declarations.

instruction: How were machine learning techniques incorporated into the analytical models developed in the related study to verify the accuracy of label declarations for marine oil dietary supplements containing EPA and DHA?
Output: In the related study, machine learning techniques were incorporated into the analytical models by using a nonlinear calibration approach based on the support vector machines (SVM) technique. The SVM technique was used to develop support vector regression (SV-R) models for quantifying the fatty acids (FAs) and FA classes in marine oil dietary supplements. These SV-R models were developed using the spectroscopic data obtained from a portable Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) device and a benchtop Fourier transform near infrared (FT-NIR) spectrometer. The incorporation of SVM allowed for improved quantification of the FAs and FA classes, resulting in higher accuracy and predictive quality compared to the traditional partial least squares regression (PLS-R) models.

instruction: Can the combination of SV-R with ATR-FTIR and/or FT-NIR spectroscopic data be considered superior to traditional methods for verifying the accuracy of label declarations for marine oil dietary supplements containing EPA and DHA?
Output: Yes, based on the findings mentioned in the text, the combination of support vector regression (SV-R) with ATR-FTIR and/or FT-NIR spectroscopic data can be considered superior to traditional methods for verifying the accuracy of label declarations for marine oil dietary supplements containing EPA and DHA. The SV-R models showed higher accuracy and predictive quality compared to the traditional partial least squares regression (PLS-R) models. The SV-R models also provided closer agreement with the certified and reference values for the prediction of EPA and DHA in the reference standard. Therefore, the combination of SV-R with spectroscopic data can potentially be used for the rapid screening of marine oil products to ensure the accuracy of label declarations.
